Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Reinforced Tension-Line Suture in Colorectal Cancer Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised in a 1:1 ratio

Participants.evidence: patients aged 18 years or older, scheduled for elective colorectal cancer surgery through a midline incision from 2017 to 2021

Intervention.evidence: RTL and 4:1 small-bite closure with polypropylene sutures (RTL group) or 4:1 small-bite closure with polydioxanone suture alone (PDS group)

Objective.evidence: The study aimed to determine if adding a reinforced tension-line (RTL) suture to the standard 4:1 small-bite closure reduces the incidence of incisional hernia following colorectal cancer surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was CT-detected incisional hernia at 1 year.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was stratified by study centre, and allocation was concealed using sequentially numbered sealed opaque envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: CT interpreters were blinded to treatment groups.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 160 patients were randomised, 80 in each group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: At 1 year, 134 patients were analysed: 63 in the RTL group and 71 in the PDS group, using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Incisional hernia was found in 4 (6%) patients in the RTL group and 15 (21%) in the PDS group (OR 3.95, 95% CI 1.24 to 12.60; P = 0.014).

Harms.evidence: No unintended effects were reported in either group.
